entries.text:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.

entries.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group

entries.text: Time to brew some perl! Perl 5.18.1 is out.
entries.title: perl 5.18.1 is now available

entries.text: Can't say that Strawberry Perl is lagging behind. Four days after 5.18.1 hits the shelves, it's back at parity.
entries.title: Strawberry Perl 5.18.1.1 released

entries.text: This one is already mentioned in the Barbie testing overview, but it deserves an entry of its own. Reini Urban shows how he smoke tests the whole of CPAN. From a single line of code. Amazing feat or terrifying bend of what the human mind can withstand. I'll let history decide...
entries.title: Smoking CPAN in one line

entries.text: Barbie covers what happened lately in the Perl testing world.
entries.title: CPAN Testers Summary - Aug 2013 - Trans-Europe Express

entries.text: Naoki Tomita shares a script that favorites CPAN modules via the command line.
entries.title: cpanmeta fav++ modules

entries.text: Of course, we all know the classic "die 'uurgh'". dakkar reminds us that there are ways to have more... articulated last words, via objects.
entries.title: Using exception classes in Perl

entries.text: If last week's post made you wonder what is plenv, Tatsuhiko Miyagawa explains it now.
entries.title: plenv, alternative for perlbrew

entries.text: For us, it's the movie Inception, but with Leonardo's role played by Fat Bastard from the Austin Powers movies. For miyagawa, it was last Sunday.
entries.title: Meta-fatpacking

entries.text: Remember those good ol' text games of yore? Ovid does too, and he wrote a Perl engine to run those vintage adventures.
entries.title: You are in a forest ...

entries.text: If you enjoyed the hacking series of Mike Doherty, now you can follow his footsteps using his new module on CPAN.
entries.title: Introducing Hack::Natas

entries.text: Jon Jensen's slides on the joys of packaging perl modules (in this case, via RPMs).
entries.title: Adventures in Perl Packaging

entries.text: An interview of Larry Wall by Jonathan Schiefer.
entries.title: Hacker Interviews: Larry Wall

entries.text: Jan Gehring's lightning talk on Rex. Because if it's worth doing more than once, it's worth automating.
entries.title: Rex  Lightning Talk

entries.text: Stanislaw Pusep's slides on LWP::Protocol::Net::Curl, a module mashing the goodness of LWP and libcurl together.
entries.title: LWP + libcurl

entries.text: Kerstin Puschke's slides on oEmbed, an open-web standard for 3rd party media embedding.
entries.title: oEmbed - hassle-free embedding of third party media content

entries.text: All of YAPC::EU's slides, conveniently aggregated together, for your viewing pleasure.
entries.title: All of YAPC::EU's Slides

entries.text: Jan Henning Thorsen mentions hypnotoad, the Mojolicious web server that can do hot deployment and introduces Toadfarm that can handle post-receive hooks of Git and Github to pull and deploy your latest and greatest version of your web application.
entries.title: Continuous deployment with #Mojolicious and @github

entries.text: This is the first of the series of YAPC::EU reports by Moritz Lenz.
entries.title: First day at YAPC::Europe 2013 in Kiev

entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: The green/yellow report of domm (Thomas Kalusner).
entries.title: Things I learned at YAPC::Europe 2013 in Kiev

entries.text: It turns out 70% of CPAN distributions aren't used by any other distribution... See more details in the report of Neil Bowers.
entries.title: Total number of dependencies

entries.text: Very few things, as most of the Perl 6 developers were at YAPC::EU.
entries.title: Perl 6 changes - 2013W33

entries.text: Are you fed up using the same names in every example script? Philippe Bruhat (BooK) came to your rescue 8 years ago. Now his module is also available as a web service.
entries.title: Acme::MetaSyntactic or how to get rid of foo and bar?

entries.text: September 19-21, 2013, Keio University Hiyoshi Campus, Tokyo, Japan
entries.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo

entries.text: October 4-5, 2013, Paris, France
entries.title: OSDC.fr

entries.text: October 4-6, 2013, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
entries.title: The Pittsburgh Perl Workshop

entries.text: November 15-16, 2013, Curitiba, PR, Brazil
entries.title: YAPC::Brazil 2013

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
chapters.title: Events

header: Summer is almost (but not quite) over. This year's edition of YAPC::EU came and went and, if the Twitter feeds are to be believed, a good time was had by all. As it is typical, it left a heap of slidedecks and videos in its wake that should keep us entertained for a few weeks still. A new maintenance release of Perl also made its appearance. Beside that, it was a fairly mundane week in the Perl world; Reini Urban smoking the whole of CPAN via a one-liner, miyagawa fatpacking fatpacked fatpackers, y'know, the usual suspects doing the usual things... ~ Yanick
Summer might be almost over for Yanick in Canada, but for me, we have 2 more months of hot weather... ~ Gabor
subject: Another YAPC, another release of Perl
